ARTICLE 121
Mayor
121.01   Powers and duties.
 
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Position established - see W. Va. Code 8-5-7
Oath - see W. Va. Code 8-5-8
Term - see W. Va. Code 8-5-9
Vacancy - see W. Va. Code 8-5-10
Voting rights - see W. Va. Code 8-9-2
Powers and duties generally - see W. Va. Code 8-10-1
Acting Mayor - see W. Va. Code 8-10-3
 
 
 
121.01 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Mayor shall be the chief executive officer of the Town and shall have
the powers and perform the duties prescribed by State law, the Codified
Ordinances and other ordinances and resolutions of Council, and he shall see
that the ordinances, orders, bylaws, acts, resolutions, rules and regulations
of Council are faithfully executed. The Mayor shall have control of the police
force; and he shall, from time to time, recommend to Council such measures as
he may deem necessary for the welfare of the Town.
(1973 Code §2-36)
ARTICLE 123
Town Manager
123.01   Qualifications; appointment; removal.
123.02   Powers and duties.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Appointment, term, powers and duties - see W. Va. Code 8-5-11
 
123.01 QUALIFICATIONS; APPOINTMENT; REMOVAL.
   (a)   The Town Manager shall be appointed by Council on the basis of his
qualifications for and his demonstrated ability to perform the duties of such
office and without regard to race, creed or political party affiliation, and he
shall be appointed by an indefinite term of office, subject to removal as
provided in this section.
   (b)   The Town Manager shall not be removed from office without good cause,
and without being afforded a hearing before Council, if the person proposed to
be removed shall, upon notice to him of the termination of his services,
request such hearing. The hearing shall be open to the public, and he shall
have the right to be represented by counsel and to have process for the
attendance of witnesses and the production of books and papers on his behalf.
However, this subsection shall not apply to any person until he has served in
such office for a period of six months following his initial appointment.
(1973 Code §2-37; Passed 5-4-23.)
123.02 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   (a)   The Town Manager shall be the general administrative officer of the
Town, and except as may be provided otherwise by State law, the Codified
Ordinances or other ordinance of Council, the administration of the Town’s
business and financial affairs and the operation of the Town’s departments,
offices and agencies shall be subject to his supervision and control. The Town
Manager shall attend all meetings of Council, unless excused, and he shall from
time to time recommend to Council such matters as he may deem desirable in the
best interests of the Town.
   (b)    The Town Manager, subject to the direction of the Huse Memorial Park
Board amd the Ordinances of the Town, shall exercise general supervision over
and be responsible for the operation and maintenance of Huse Memorial Park.
   (c)    The Town Manager shall be charged with the responsibility of hiring,
discharging and maintaining supervision over all employees of the Huse Memorial
Park Board and all other Town employees, with the exception of police officers
and fire fighters and shall, with the advice and consent of Council, be charged
with the responsibility of hiring, discharging and supervision all such
employees and supervisory personnel of such Boards and of the Town, with the
exception of police officers and fire fighters. Subject to the foregoing
provisions of this subsection, the Town Manager may assign any Town officer or
employee who is subject to his supervision and orders to perform services in
anyone or more departments, offices and agencies of the Town government as the
need for such services may occur.
   (d)   The Town Manager may promulgate, and require compliance with, rules
and regulations not inconsistent with State law, the Codified Ordinances, or
other ordinance or resolution of Council for the efficient organization and
operation of the Town government.
   (e)   The Town Manager shall prepare and submit to Council the proposed
annual budget, and prepare and make recommendations, by a monthly budget
report, to the Mayor and Council with respect to financial and fiscal policies.
   (f)   Except as may be provided otherwise by State law, the Codified
Ordinances or other ordinance, the Town Manager shall make and execute all
contracts, deeds and other instruments in writing on behalf of the Town,
subject to such directives as may be given him by Council from time to time and
entered in the journal of the Council.
(1973 Code §2-38; Passed 5-4-23; Passed 10-17-24.)
ARTICLE 125
Town Attorney
125.01   Defense of Town officers; employees.
125.02   Claims against the Town.
125.03   Appointment; term; qualifications; absence.
125.04   Powers and duties.
125.05   Employment of special counsel.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Hiring special counsel - see W. Va. Code 8-10-1a
 
 
 
125.01 DEFENSE OF TOWN OFFICERS; EMPLOYEES.
   The Town Attorney shall defend Town officers and employees against all
claims, demands, actions, suits, prosecutions and other proceedings brought
against them for their acts or omissions while acting in good faith in line of
duty.
(1973 Code §1-8(b))
125.02 CLAIMS AGAINST THE TOWN.
   No action shall be maintained against the Town for injury to any person or
property or for wrongful death alleged to have been sustained by reason of the
negligence of the Town, or of any officer, agent or employee thereof, unless a
written verified statement by the claimant, his agent, attorney or
representative of the nature of the claim and of the time and place at which
the injury is alleged to have occurred or been received shall have been filed
with the Mayor, Recorder or Town Attorney within thirty days after such cause
of action shall have accrued. The cause of action shall be deemed to have
accrued on the date of the sustaining of the injury, except that where death
results therefrom the time for the personal representative to give notice shall
run from the date of death. An action at law for damages for injury to any
person or property or for wrongful death shall not be commenced until the
expiration of thirty days after the filing of the notice provided for in this
section.
(1973 Code §1-9)
125.03 APPOINTMENT; TERM; QUALIFICATIONS; ABSENCE.
   (a)   The Town Attorney shall be retained by Council, for such term of
office and for such compensation as shall be agreed upon by him and Council,
and such agreement may provide that in the event of his absence, illness,
disability or other exigency his partner in the practice of law or some other
qualified attorney may act as his deputy, on such terms as may be provided in
the aforesaid agreement.
   (b)   The Town Attorney shall be a member in good standing of the bar of
Fayette County. (1973 Code §2-43)
125.04 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Town Attorney shall:
   (a)   Be the legal adviser, attorney and counsel for Council and its
committees, the Mayor and Town Manager, and all officers, boards and
commissions of the Town government, and; upon their written request, he shall
render to them his written opinion on any legal matter pertaining to their
official duties.
   (b)   Prepare all official bonds, contracts, deeds and other instruments in
writing in which the Town is concerned and shall endorse thereon his approval
as to form.
   (c)   Prepare all ordinances for presentation to Council and, at the request
of any member of Council, he shall prepare any resolution which is to be
presented to Council.
   (d)   When so directed by the Town Manager or Council, represent the Town in
the Municipal Court and in all courts of record, including cases on appeal.
   (e)   Perform such other professional duties as may be required of him by
Council, in accord with the agreement between him and Council.
      (1973 Code §2-43; Passed 5-4-23.)
125.05 EMPLOYMENT OF SPECIAL COUNSEL.
   Council, whenever the exigencies of the business of the Town require such
action, shall have the right to employ special counsel to assist the Town
Attorney.
(1973 Code §2-44)
ARTICLE 127
Recorder
127.01   Availability of Town books and records.
127.02   Preservation of records; general duties.
127.03   Acting Mayor.
127.04   Financial statement.
127.05   Notice of levies.
127.06   Review of Town checks.
127.07   Property and property insurance inventories.
127.08   Fees for copies of records and documents.
127.09       Fees for freedom of information request.
 
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Position established - see W. Va. Code 8-5-7
Oath - see W. Va. Code 8-5-8
Term - see W. Va. Code 8-5-9
Vacancy - see W. Va. Code 8-5-10
Voting rights - see W. Va. Code 8-9-2
Powers and duties generally - see W. Va. Code 8-10-3
 
 
127.01 AVAILABILITY OF TOWN BOOKS AND RECORDS.
   (a)   Except as may be provided otherwise by State law, the Codified
Ordinances or other ordinance to safeguard the security of license tax returns
and other confidential information, all records, books, maps, documents and
other papers which are maintained on file in any Town office shall be open for
inspection and use by residents of the Town and others having an interest
therein during all regular business hours, but none shall be removed from the
office of its custodian except by authority of the Mayor, Town Manager, Council
or a valid subpoena duces tecum issuing from a court or officer having
jurisdiction in the premises.
   (b)   No person shall, without proper authority as provided in subsection
(a) hereof, remove from the office of its custodian any record, book, map,
document or other paper which is maintained on file in any Town office, nor
shall any person fail to return any such item to its proper custodian within
the time set by the custodian for its return.
   (c)   No person shall willfully destroy, obliterate, secrete, deface, mark
upon, disturb the arrangement of, damage or otherwise tamper with any record,
book, map, document or other paper which is maintained on file in any Town
office.
(1973 Code §2-9; Passed 5-4-23.)
127.02 PRESERVATION OF RECORDS; GENERAL DUTIES.
   (a)   The Recorder shall have charge of and preserve all Town records the
custody of which is not assigned to another Town officer, and he shall have
authority to attest and affix the Town seal to all Town records in all cases
which require such action.
   (b)   He shall have such other powers and perform such other duties as
prescribed by the Codified Ordinances and other ordinances and resolutions of
Council, and as prescribed by State law for Recorders generally.
(1973 Code §2-39)
127.03 ACTING MAYOR.
   Whenever the Mayor is unable to perform the duties of his office because of
illness or absence from the Town, and during any vacancy in the office of
Mayor, the Recorder shall perform the duties of the Mayor and be vested with
all his powers and authority.
(1973 Code §2-39)
127.04 FINANCIAL STATEMENT.
   Each year, immediately after the meeting of Council mentioned in Section
111.05, the Recorder shall forward to the State Tax Commissioner a certified
copy of the financial statement made at such meeting, and he shall publish a
copy thereof forthwith.
(1973 Code §2-39)
127.05 NOTICE OF LEVIES.
   Each year, within three days after Council has laid the levies, the Recorder
shall forward certified copies of the order laying the levies to the State Tax
Commissioner, the State Auditor and the County Assessor.
(1973 Code §2-39)
127.06 REVIEW OF TOWN CHECKS.
   The Recorder shall review all cancelled checks and all checkbook stubs of
the Town at least once each month, and record on the checkbooks that such
inspection has been made and the date of each such inspection.
(1973 Code §2-39)
127.07 PROPERTY AND PROPERTY INSURANCE INVENTORIES.
   (a)   The Recorder shall maintain on file in his office an inventory of all
real property owned or leased to the Town, including rights of way and
easements. This inventory shall be maintained in current status, and during
January of each year shall be revised, as may be appropriate, to show changes
in value due to depreciation or repairs, renovations, etc. For each building or
lot, or right of way or easement, such inventory shall show:
      (1)   A brief description;
      (2)   A reference to the deed, devise, lease or other instrument whereby
the Town acquired title to or the use thereof;
      (3)   The department, office or agency charged with custody;
      (4)   The purpose or use;
      (5)   The insurance of all types thereon, together with notes as to
premiums payable and anniversary dates; and
      (6)   For property owned by the Town and leased to other persons, copies
of such leases and appropriate notes as to the revenues derived therefrom.
   (b)   Each Town officer having custody of items of nonexpendable personal
property of value greater than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) owned by or leased
to the Town shall, during January of each year, prepare in duplicate an
itemized inventory of such property, showing for each item:
      (1)   Its value and a brief description, together with identification (by
serial number, where applicable);
      (2)   A reference to the instrument, if any, whereby title or use was
acquired;
      (3)   The department, office or agency, having custody;
      (4)   The purpose or use; and
      (5)   The insurance of all types, if any, together with notes as to
premiums payable and anniversary dates.
   The original copy of each such inventory shall be filed in the office of the
Recorder before February 1, of each year, and the duplicate copy shall be
retained on file in the office of the person who prepared it.
(1973 Code §2-35)
127.08 FEES FOR COPIES OF RECORDS AND DOCUMENTS.
   The Town of Fayetteville shall charge the following fees in connection with
copies and/or research; however, no charge shall be made for such copies
supplied to the Town or any other governmental unit, or any of their agencies,
bureaus, departments, divisions or instrumentalities, and members of the
Council for their official use.
 
Copies             Twenty-five cents (.25) per page
Computer printouts Twenty-five cents (.25) per page
Clerical time      Sixteen dollars ($16.00) per hour
Professional time  Fifty-five dollars ($55.00) per hour or any portion thereof
Research time      Twenty-seven dollars ($27.00) per hour or any portion
                   thereof
(Ord. 2012-3. Passed 7-5-12; Passed 6-3-21.)
127.09 FEES FOR FREEDOM OF INFORMATION REQUEST.
   There shall be assessed a fee for providing information requested pursuant
to the West Virginia Freedom of Information Act of fifty cents ($0.50) per page
or in the event it is to be done electronically it shall be the cost of a
computer flash drive (commonly referred to as a thumb drive). (Passed 7-21-22.)
ARTICLE 129
Treasurer
129.01   Collection of moneys owed Town.
129.02   Disbursement from Town Treasury.
129.03   Claims against the Town.
129.04   Fiscal reports; year.
129.05   Procurement and contracting by Town.
129.06   Accounts; records and collection procedures.
129.07   Annual financial statement.
129.08   Miscellaneous powers and duties.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Supervision of public offices - see W. Va. Code Art. 6-9
Purchasing; competitive bidding - see W. Va. Code 8-12-10
Collection of moneys - see W. Va. Code 8-13-15 et seq.
Financial statements - see W. Va. Code 8-13-23
Accounting principles; funds - see W. Va. Code 8-13-18 et seq.
 
 
 
129.01 COLLECTION OF MONEYS OWED TOWN.
   Except as may be provided otherwise by State law, the Codified Ordinances or
other ordinances of Council, all taxes, fines, special assessments, license
fees and other money due to the Town shall be collected by and paid to the
Treasurer, who shall promptly deposit such money to the credit of the Town in
such depository as may be designated by ordinance, resolution or order of
Council.
(1973 Code §2-3)
129.02 DISBURSEMENT FROM TOWN TREASURY.
   (a)   No money shall be paid out of the Town treasury except upon an order
signed by the Town officers authorized by Council to sign such order.
(1973 Code §2-4)
   (b)   Disbursements from the General Fund shall be as directed by Council
from time to time, and checks shall be prepared by the Treasurer and then shall
be signed by the Mayor and Recorder. (Passed 3-5-09)
   (c)   The Town Manager or, in his absence or disability, the person
exercising the authority of the Town Manager, is hereby authorized to order
disbursements from the General Fund, from money on hand and appropriated for
such purpose, for any of the following purposes:
      (1)   The payment of utility bills such as, for example, electric light,
gas and telephone services;
      (2)   The Town payroll;
      (3)   Duly authorized charge accounts such as, for example, gasoline and
oil for Town motor vehicles, office supplies and miscellaneous purchases; and
      (4)   Miscellaneous items from the petty cash fund, if and when a petty
cash fund is currently authorized by Council.
         (1973 Code §2-4; Passed 5-4-23.)
129.03 CLAIMS AGAINST THE TOWN.
   Each person having a bill, claim or demand against the Town shall file with
the Recorder an accurate account or statement thereof, fully setting forth each
item and the authority therefor. The Recorder shall present each such account
or statement to Council at its next meeting after such filing, at which time
such account or statement shall be considered by Council and may be allowed in
whole or in part, or wholly disallowed, and Council shall then direct the
Treasurer accordingly.
(1973 Code §2-5)
129.04 FISCAL REPORTS; YEAR.
   All fiscal reports, settlements, accounts and statements of the Town and of
Town officers shall conform to the fiscal year, which begins on July 1, of each
calendar year and terminates at the close of business June 30, of the next
succeeding calendar year.
(1973 Code §2-6)
129.05 PROCUREMENT AND CONTRACTING BY TOWN.
   (a)   Competitive Procurement.
      (1)   Competitive bidding. All procurement and contracts awarded by the
Town over $10,000 shall be accomplished by competitively sealed bidding except
as otherwise provided hereinbelow, or as provided by State law.
      (2)   Competitive sealed proposals. When, if so authorized by the Town
Council, the Town Manager determines, and when not required by law, that the
use of competitive sealed bidding is either not practicable or not advantageous
to the Town, a procurement may be had, or a contract entered into, by use of
the competitive sealed proposals method. Such proposals shall be solicited
through a request for proposals and adequate public notice of the request shall
be given in the same manner as with competitive sealed bidding.
      (3)   Small purchases. Any procurement or contract of less than $10,000
may be made and entered into in accordance with the small purchases procedures
authorized in this subsection.
         A.   Contract or procurement requirements shall not be artificially
divided so as to constitute a small purchase under this subsection.
         B.   The Town Manager shall adopt operational procedures for making
small purchases. Such operational procedures shall provide for obtaining
adequate and reasonable competition by written or oral quotation for the
supply, service or construction being purchased. Award shall be made to the
business or other entity offering the lowest acceptable quotation. Adequate
records to document the competition obtained shall be maintained.
   (b)   Non-Competitive Procurement.
      (1)   General. Procurement may be made or a contract awarded without
competition when a department head determines, and the Town Manager concurs in
writing, and it is not otherwise required by law, after conducting a good faith
review of available sources, that the contract or procurement by its very
nature is not suitable to competitive bids or proposals. Examples of
procurement or contracts which may not be suitable for competitive bids or
proposals include, but are not necessarily limited to the following:
         A.   There is only one source for the required supply, service or
construction item;
         B.   A sole supplier’s item is needed for trial use or testing;
         C.   Products are bought for over-the-counter resale;
         D.   Purchases of used equipment or vehicles; and
         E.   Purchases at auctions.
      (2)   Negotiation. The Town Manager or responsible department head shall
conduct negotiations, as appropriate, as to price, terms and delivery.
   (c)   Emergency Procedures. Notwithstanding any other provisions of this
section, the Town Council or Manager may make emergency procurement of
supplies, equipment, services or construction items when there exists a threat
to public health, welfare or safety, or to prevent or minimize serious
disruption of government services or operations; provided, that such emergency
procurements shall be made with such competition as is practicable under the
circumstances. A written determination of the basis for the emergency and for
the selection of the particular contractor or vendor shall be made and
maintained. A confirming resolution which includes such written determination
shall be considered by the Town Council at any meeting thereof immediately
following such emergency action for all emergency procurements or contracts of
$10,000 or more.
   (d)   Surplus Property of the United States and State of West Virginia. The
Town may enter into contracts with the United States of America, the State of
West Virginia, or with any department, division or agency thereof, for the
purpose of accepting gifts and for the purchase, sale, exchange, lease, or
transfer of any equipment, supplies, materials, or other property for cash,
credit or other property, with or without warranty, and upon such other terms
and conditions as the Federal or State governments, or the department, division
or agency thereof, deems proper, without regard to the provisions of this
section which may require, among other things, inviting or receiving of
competitive bids or the making of purchases from the lowest and best bidder.
(Passed 11-8-01; Passed 5-4-23.)
129.06 ACCOUNTS; RECORDS AND COLLECTION PROCEDURES.
   (a)   The Treasurer, under the direction of the Town Manager, shall
establish and maintain the accounting system and fiscal records of the Town
except such as may by law, the Codified Ordinances or other ordinance of the
Town be the responsibility of some other office, board, commission or agency.
The budgeting system and financial accounts and records established by the
Treasurer shall be in conformity with the requirements of the State Auditor as
provided in the West Virginia Code.
   (b)   The Treasurer shall keep complete books of account showing all
financial transactions of the Town and each department, all receipts and
expenditures made by the Town, and sources of all income and the purposes of
all expenditures. He shall enter in the municipal assessment docket all special
assessments made for public improvements, showing the name of the owner of the
property, the particular property on which the assessment is levied, the date
of the entry, and the minute book and page showing the entry of the ordinance
creating the assessment, and the maturing time of the assessment. When and as
installments upon principal and interest on each assessment shall be paid, he
shall enter such payments showing the amount paid upon principal and the amount
on interest, under the heading and in the account of such special assessment.
When the special assessment, principal and interest shall have been paid in
full, he shall make an entry in red ink on the face of the account showing that
the special assessment is fully satisfied and paid.
   (c)   Except as may be otherwise provided by law, the Codified Ordinances or
other ordinance, the Treasurer shall collect and promptly pay into the Town
treasury all taxes, fines, special assessments and other money due the Town.
All such taxes, fines, special assessments, except assessments for permanent or
semipermanent public improvements, and other money due the Town are hereby
declared to be debts owing to the Town, for which the debtor shall be
personally liable, and the Treasurer may enforce this liability by appropriate
civil action in any court of competent jurisdiction, and is hereby vested with
the same rights to distrain for the saem as is vested in the sheriff for the
collection of taxes. (A.O.; Passed 5-4-23.)
129.07 ANNUAL FINANCIAL STATEMENT.
   (a)   The Treasurer, within one hundred and twenty days after the beginning
of each fiscal year, shall prepare on a form to be prescribed by the State Tax
Commissioner and cause to be published a sworn statement revealing:
      (1)   The receipts and expenditures of the Town during the previous
fiscal year arranged under descriptive headings;
      (2)   The name of each person who received money from any fund during the
previous fiscal year, together with the amount received and the purpose for
which paid; and
      (3)   All debts of the Town; the purpose for which each debt was
contracted, its due date, and to what date the interest thereon has been paid;
provided, that all salaries, receipts, payments to each individual vendor and
expenditures to employees of municipal offices, companies and departments may
be published in the aggregate.
   (b)   The Treasurer shall transmit to any resident of the Town, upon
request, a copy of any such statement for the fiscal year designated.
   (c)   The statement required by subsection (a) hereof shall be sworn to by
the Treasurer, the Mayor and two councilmen. As soon as practicable following
the close of the fiscal year, a copy of any statement herein required shall be
filed by the Treasurer with the State Tax Commissioner, and the Clerk of the
County Commission of the County, and the Clerk of the Circuit Court of the
County.
(1973 Code §2-41)
129.08 MISCELLANEOUS POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Treasurer, under the direction of the Town Manager, shall:
   (a)   Prepare and submit to the Town Manager, Mayor and Council such
financial and fiscal reports as they may require.
   (b)   Prepare all vouchers and payrolls relating to items and personnel
subject to his authority.
   (c)   Conduct such routine audits as may from time to time be required by
the Town Manager, Mayor and Council.
   (d)   Prescribe rules for the collection of coins from parking meters and
for other collections of money, and the method of accounting therefor and
payment thereof into the Town treasury.
   (e)   Perform such other duties and exercise such other powers as may be
prescribed by State law for municipal treasurers and as may be prescribed for
him by the Codified Ordinances and other ordinances, resolutions and directives
of Council and the Town Manager.
      (1973 Code §2-42; Passed 5-4-23.)
ARTICLE 131
Town Engineer (Repealed)
   EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Article
131 was repealed by an Ordinance passed October 1, 2020.
ARTICLE 133
Planning Commission
133.01   Commission continued.
133.02   Composition and organization; qualifications; appointment and terms of
members; filling vacancies.
133.03      Powers and duties of the Planning Commission.
133.04      Compensation and expenses of members.
133.05      Expenditures; gifts of Commission.
133.06      Planning Commission meetings; quorum; open meetings requirements.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Authority to establish - see W. Va. Code 8A-2-1
General provisions - see W. Va. Code 8A-2-3
Adoption of comprehensive plan - see W. Va. Code Art. 8A-3
Approval of subdivision plats - see W. Va. Code 8A-5-4 et seq.
Zoning recommendations - see W. Va. Code 8A-7-4 et seq.
 
 
133.01 COMMISSION CONTINUED.
   There is hereby continued as re-named herein, for the benefit of the
residents of the Town and the surrounding environs, the “Fayetteville Municipal
Planning Commission”, pursuant to and in accordance with the provisions of
Chapter 8A, Article 2 of the West Virginia Code, as amended. (Passed 9-16-03.)
133.02 COMPOSITION AND ORGANIZATION; QUALIFICATIONS; APPOINTMENT AND TERMS OF
MEMBERS; FILLING VACANCIES.
   (a)   Composition. Planning Commission members shall be appointed and
confirmed by the Town Council. The Planning Commission shall consist of eight
(8) members. One member must be a member of the Town Council or its designee,
and one member must be a member of the administrative office of the Mayor or
the Mayor's designee. The terms of membership for those two (2) members are the
same as their terms of office and neither shall serve more than two (2)
consecutive terms. Of the six (6) remaining members of the Planning Commission,
the positions must be filled to fairly represent different areas of interest,
knowledge, and expertise, including, but not limited to business, industry,
labor, government, and other relevant disciplines. All appointees to the
Planning Commission shall be residents of the Town, and at least three-fifths
(3/5) of those appointed shall have been residents of Fayetteville for a period
of at least three (3) years prior to confirmation.
   (b)   Terms of Service. The terms of the six (6) remaining appointees shall
be staggered Three year terms.
   (c)   Removal. The Town Council may establish procedures for the removal of
members of the Planning Commission for inactivity, neglect of duty, or
malfeasance. The procedures must contain provisions requiring that the person
to be removed be provided with a written statement of the reasons for removal
and an opportunity to be heard on the matter.
   (d)   Filling Vacancies. Should a vacancy arise on the Planning Commission
for any reason during the duration of a term, the vacancy shall be filled for
the unexpired term in the same manner as provided hereinabove.
   (e)   Officers. At the first meeting each year the members of the Commission
shall elect from among its members a President and Vice President.
      (1)   The President shall preside over all meetings of the Planning
Commission and over all public hearings and public meetings called by the
Planning Commission. The President shall transmit reports, plans,
recommendations, and other documents from the Planning Commission to all
appropriate authorities or bodies. The President shall act as spokesperson for
the Planning Commission.
      (2)   In the President's absence, the Vice-President shall have the power
and authority to act as President of the Planning Commission. The Vice-
President shall perform additional duties and functions as may be required by
the Planning Commission.
      (3)   In the absence of both the President and Vice-President and, as
long as there is a quorum, the members present shall elect a President pro
tempore, who shall only act as President for the durtion of the meeting.
         (Passed 12-1-22.)
133.03 POWERS AND DUTIES OF THE PLANNING COMMISSION.
   The Planning Commission has the following powers and duties, in accordance
with W. Va. Code §8A-2-11:
   (a)   Exercise general supervision for the administration of the affairs of
the Commission;
   (b)   Prescribe rules and regulations pertaining to administration,
investigations and hearings: Provided, That the rules and regulations are
adopted by the Town Council;
   (c)   Supervise the fiscal affairs and responsibilities of the Commission;
   (d)   With consent from the Town Council, hire employees necessary to carry
out the duties and responsibilities of the Planning Commission; Provided, that
the Town Council sets the salaries;
   (e)   Keep an accurate and complete record of all Planning Commission
proceedings;
   (f)   Record and file all bonds and contracts;
   (g)   Take responsibility for the custody and preservation of all papers and
documents of the Planning Commission;
   (h)   Make recommendations to the Town Council concerning Planning;
   (i)   Make an annual report to the Town Council concerning the operation of
the Planning Commission and the status of planning within its jurisdiction;
   (j)   Prepare, publish and distribute reports, ordinances and other material
relating to the activities authorized under this article;
   (k)   Adopt a seal and certify all official acts;
   (l)   Invoke any legal, equitable or special remedy for the enforcement of
the provisions of this article or any ordinance, rule and regulation or action
taken thereunder;
   (m)   Prepare and submit an annual budget to the Town Council;
   (n)   If necessary, establish advisory committees;
   (o)   Delegate limited powers to a committee composed of one or more members
of the Commission; and
   (p)   Contract for special or temporary services and profession counsel with
the approval of the governing body. Upon request, a town prosecuting attorney
or any other town employee may render assistance and service to the Planning
Commission without compensation. (Passed 12-1-22.)
133.04 COMPENSATION AND EXPENSES OF MEMBERS.
   Members of the Planning Commission shall serve without compensation but
shall be reimbursed for actual expenses reasonably incurred in the performance
of their official duties.
(Passed 12-1-22.)
133.05 EXPENDITURES; GIFTS OF COMMISSION.
   (a)   The Town Council shall authorize expenditures reasonable necessary to
acquire:
      (1)   Suitable offices for the holding of meetings and the preservation
of plans, maps, documents and accounts; and
      (2)   Appropriate money to defray the reasonable expenses of the Planning
Commission.
   (b)   The Commission shall have authority to accept gifts, funds and
donations which will be deposited with the Town Treasurer in a special non-
reverting Planning Commission fund to be available for expenditures by the
Planning Commission for the purpose designated by the donor.
(Passed 12-1-22.)
133.06 PLANNING COMMISSION MEETINGS; QUORUM; OPEN MEETINGS REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   Regular Meetings. Pursuant to W. Va. Code §8A-2-7, the Planning
Commission shall meet a least quarterly and may meet more frequently at the
request of the President or by two (2) or more members. The Planning Commission
shall make its own rules of procedure and determine the time of the meeting.
   (b)   Special Meetings. Notice for a special meeting must be in writing,
include the date, time, place, and purpose of the special meeting. Notice for a
special meeting must be posted and sent to all members at least two (2)
business days before the special meeting.
   (c)   Quorum. Pursuant to W. Va. Code §8A-2-8 the Planning Commission must
have a quorum to conduct a meeting. A simple majority of the Planning
Commission members present (minimum of five (5)) constitute a quorum. No action
of the Planning Commission is official unless authorized by a majority of the
members present at a regular or properly called special meeting.
   (d)   Open Meetings and Public Record. All Planning Commission meetings
shall be open to the public unless discussing matters that are permitted under
W. Va. Code §6-9A-4 as an exception to the State's open governmental proceeding
act. The Planning Commission shall follow all rules and regulations pertaining
to notice, setting the agenda, and taking minutes for each meeting. (Passed 12-
1-22.)
ARTICLE 135
Police Department
135.01   Composition; mission statement.
135.02   Appointment.
135.03   Chief of Police.
135.04   Chain of command.
135.05   General powers and duties.
135.06   Complainant oaths; arrest warrants.
135.07   Rules and regulations.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Appointment of special police - see W. Va. Code 8-10-1
Powers and duties - see W. Va. Code 8-14-1, 8-14-3
Hours of duty; holidays - see W. Va. Code 8-14-2, 8-14-2a
School zone officers - see W. Va. Code 8-14-5
Parking lot or building officers - see W. Va. Code 8-14-5a
Civil service - see W. Va. Code 8-14-7 et seq.
Pension and relief fund - see W. Va. Code Art. 8-22
 
 
 
135.01 COMPOSITION; MISSION STATEMENT.
   The Police Department shall consist of such personnel, having such ranks, as
may from time to time be provided by Council.
(1973 Code §20-1)
   (a)   In partnership with all segments of the Fayetteville community, the
Fayetteville Police Department will provide for the general protection, safety
and well being of the residents, businesses and visitors of the Town. This will
be accomplished through a proactive approach in the prevention, deterrence,
detection and investigation of criminal activity. The Police Department will
seek to contribute to the highest quality of life for the Town of Fayetteville
through the assistance, cooperation, involvement and interaction of the
citizenry. All activities of the Police Department will be conducted in
accordance with the laws of the Town of Fayetteville, State of West Virginia
and the United States of America.
   (b)   (1)   Police canine teams are maintained by the Department as a
valuable law enforcement tool for use in criminal apprehension, evidence
detection, crowd control, and public relations activities. These teams assist
the Department in serving the citizens, businesses and visitors of our Town.
With this goal in mind, we strive to implement the most efficient and effective
methods and tools available to us.
      (2)   Use of a Department canine for specific law enforcement objective
including, but not limited to:
         A.   Building searches,
         B.   Tracking,
         C.   Crime scene or area searches for items of evidence,
         D.   Narcotic searches,
         E.   Criminal apprehension (on or off leash),
         F.   Protection of the handler, other officers or the canine,
         G.   Crowd control during civil disorders,
         H.   Contraband detection,
         I.   Educational or demonstration purposes.
            (Passed 8-2-07)
135.02 APPOINTMENT.
   The Chief of Police and all police officers of the Town shall be appointed
by the Council and they shall serve at the will and pleasure of Council;
provided, that this section shall not be construed so as to prohibit the Mayor
from appointing special police officers whenever he deems it necessary, as
provided in West Virginia Code 8-10-1.
(1973 Code §20-2)
135.03 CHIEF OF POLICE.
   The Chief of Police, subject to the statutory authority of the Mayor, shall
be head of the Police Department and the commanding officer of the police force
of the Town. The Chief of Police shall be responsible for the administration,
training, discipline and morale of the personnel of the Police Department and
for their effective and efficient employment to prevent crime, apprehend law
violators, maintain law and order and enforce State law, the Codified
Ordinances and other ordinances within the Town. The Chief of Police, prior to
being employed by the Town, shall be a certified police officer in the State of
West Virginia.
(Ord. 2012-6. Passed 10-4-12.)
135.04 CHAIN OF COMMAND.
   Each police officer shall obey the lawful orders of his superiors in the
chain of command.
(1973 Code §20-4)
135.05 GENERAL POWERS AND DUTIES.
   (a)   The Chief of Police and each police officer shall have all of the
powers, authority, rights and privileges within the corporate limits of the
Town with regard to the arrest of persons, the collection of claims, and the
execution and return of any search warrant, warrant of arrest or other process,
which can legally be exercised or discharged by a constable of a district
within the Town. In order to arrest for the violation of Town ordinances and as
to all matters arising within the corporate limits and coming within the scope
of his official duties, the powers of the Chief of Police and any police
officer shall extend anywhere within the County, and shall have the same
authority of pursuit and arrest beyond his normal jurisdiction as has the
sheriff of Fayette County. For an offense committed in his presence, any such
officer may arrest the offender without a warrant and take him before the Mayor
to be dealt with according to law. He and his sureties shall be liable to all
the fines, penalties and forfeitures which a constable of a district is liable
to, for any failure or dereliction in such office, to be recovered in the same
manner and in the same courts in which such fines, penalties and forfeitures
are recovered against a constable.
   (b)   It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police and each police officer to
aid in the enforcement of the criminal laws of the State within the Town,
independently of any provision of the Codified Ordinances or other ordinance or
lack of an ordinance with respect thereto, and to cause the arrest of or arrest
any offender. Failure on the part of each officer to discharge any duty imposed
by the provisions of this section shall be deemed official misconduct for which
he may be removed from office. Any such officer shall have the same authority
to execute a warrant and the same authority to arrest without a warrant for
offenses committed in his presence, as a constable. (1973 Code §20-5)
135.06 COMPLAINANT OATHS; ARREST WARRANTS.
   In addition to the Mayor, the Chief of Police and, in the absence from the
station house of the Chief of Police, the next senior police officer present,
shall have authority to administer oaths to complainants and to issue arrest
warrants thereon for all violations of the Codified Ordinances and other
ordinances of the Town.
(1973 Code §20-6)
135.07 RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Mayor, in consultation with the Chief of Police, may from time to time
promulgate and amend rules and regulations not inconsistent with State law, the
Codified Ordinances or other ordinance of the Town for the government of the
Police Department and the conduct of its members. Such rules and regulations,
when approved by resolution of Council, shall be obeyed and complied with by
all members of the Police Department.
(1973 Code §20-7)
ARTICLE 137
Fire Department
137.01   Established; composition; appointment of Chief and Assistant Chief.
137.02   Powers and duties.
137.03   Compensation.
137.04   Response to calls.
137.05   Obedience to orders; dismissal.
137.06   Central fire station.
137.07   Rules and regulations.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Power of governing body - see W. Va. Code 8-15-1
Fire protection contracts - see W. Va. Code 8-15-3, 8-12-5(57)
Volunteer fire companies - see W. Va. Code 8-15-4 et seq.
Pension and relief fund - see W. Va. Code Art. 8-22
Authority of local fire departments - see W. Va. Code Art. 29-3A
 
 
 
137.01 ESTABLISHED; COMPOSITION; APPOINTMENT OF CHIEF AND ASSISTANT CHIEF.
   There is hereby created the Town Fire Department, which shall consist of a
Fire Chief, who shall be nominated by the Mayor and appointed by the Town
Council. There shall also be an Assistant Fire Chief, who shall be recommended
by the Fire Chief, and subject to approval by the Town Council. Both the Fire
Chiefand Assistant Fire Chief shall serve at the discretion of the Town
Council. (Passed 4-4-24.)
137.02 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   (a)   The Fire Chief shall have active charge, supervision and control of
the selection and appointment of members of the Fire Department, and of the
management, direction and supervision of the Fire Department and shall be
charged with and accountable for all of the fire equipment and property
belonging to the Town. In the absence of the Fire Chief, the assistant Fire
Chief shall have and exercise all of the powers and duties of the Fire Chief.
   (b)   The Fire Chief, and in his absence, the assistant Fire Chief, shall
have authority to direct the pulling down or destroying of any fence, house,
building or other thing, if deemed necessary to prevent the spreading of fire.
(1973 Code §9-17; Passed 4-4-24.)
137.03 COMPENSATION.
   The Fire Chief, assistant Fire Chief and members of the Fire Department
shall receive no salary or compensation as such, but shall be paid by the Town
a reasonable compensation for time and service actually expended in protecting
property within the Town from fires, conflagrations, riots or other work
properly within the scope of their duties. Such compensation shall from time to
time be fixed by Council
(1973 Code §9-18)
137.04 RESPONSE TO CALLS.
   (a)   The Fire Department shall answer all calls for fires, conflagrations,
riots or other disasters within the Town by day or night, and the Fire Chief
shall keep an accurate register or record of all members of the department who
respond and who fail to respond to such calls.
   (b)   The Fire Department shall also answer all calls for fires,
conflagrations, riots and other disasters elsewhere beyond the Town limits as
shall be required of it by its agreement for mutual aid set out by the
agreement with the other members of the Fayette County Firemen’s Association,
Inc., and the Fayette County Office of Emergency Services. The Fire Chief shall
keep an accurate register or record of all members of the department who
respond and who fail to respond to such calls.
(Passed 4-4-24.)
137.05 OBEDIENCE TO ORDERS; DISMISSAL.
   If any member of the Fire Department fails or refuses, without just or
sufficient cause, to answer or obey any summons or lawful order of the Fire
Chief, or shall fail or refuse to obey any summons or lawful order of the
assistant Fire Chief, or fails or refuses to submit to or be governed by the
provisions of this article and the rules and regulations of the Fire
Department, he may be dismissed from the Fire Department by the Fire Chief.
(1973 Code §9-20)
137.06 CENTRAL FIRE STATION.
   The Fire Department shall have a central station or location to be
designated by Council, and suitable means or methods provided for the storage
of its equipment, and due notice given to the inhabitants of the Town of the
location thereof, together with the means of communication with the Fire Chief
or other member of the Fire Department in case of fire or other disaster.
(1973 Code §9-21)
137.07 RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Mayor, in consultation with the Fire Chief, may from time to time
promulgate and amend rules and regulations not inconsistent with State law, the
Codified Ordinances or other ordinance of the Town for the government of the
Fire Department and the conduct of its members. Such rules and regulations,
when approved by resolution of Council, shall be obeyed and complied with by
all members of the Fire Department.
(1973 Code §9-22)
ARTICLE 139
Board of Park and Recreation Commissioners
