139.01 ESTABLISHMENT.
   A Board of Park and Recreation Commissioners is hereby established. The
Board shall be a public corporate body with perpetual existence and a common
seal. It shall be known as the Board of Park and Recreation Commissioners of
Fayetteville, West Virginia. It shall have the power to receive any gift,
grant, donation, bequest, or devise in its own name or in the name of the Town;
sue and be sued; contract and be contracted with; and do any and all things and
acts which may be necessary, appropriate, convenient or incidental to carry out
and effectuate the purposes and provisions of this article.
(Passed 10-4-84.)
139.02 MEMBERSHIP; TERM.
    (a)   The Board of Park and Recreation Commissioners shall consist of not
less than five, nor more than seven members; the majority of whom shall
constitute a quorum for the transaction o business. Each member of the Board
must be a resident of the Municipality. The appointment of the members thereof
shall be by Council. Membership on Council shall not disqualify any member from
being appointed to the Board. Two members of Council, if otherwise qualified,
may be appointed to the Board. The term of the Board membership of any such
member of Council so appointed shall continue during his term as member and
Council, and until his successor is appointed or elected and qualified. The
terms of other appointed members shall be four years, except for the initial
appointment as hereinafter stated, and until their successors have been duly
appointed and qualified. Council shall appoint the members of the Board, such
first appointments as provided in that certain ordinance passed 10-4-84, to
serve one for a term of four years, two for a term of two years, and two for a
term of one year. The two new appointees provided for by ordinance enacted 12-
6-90 shall be appointed for a term of four years beginning July 1, 1991. The
Council is hereby authorized to make an interim appointment from the date of
passage of this article of the two said new members to serve from said
appointment until June 30, 1991. When any member of the Board, during his term
of office, shall cease to be a resident of the Municipality, he shall thereby
be disqualified as a member of the Board, and his office shall, thereupon,
become vacant.
(Passed 12-6-90.)
   (b)   No member shall serve on the Board for more than two consecutive
terms.
(Ord. 2017-10. Passed 12-7-17.)
139.03 VACANCY.
   When a vacancy occurs on the Board of Park and Recreation Commissioners by
reason of death, resignation, change of residence from the Municipality,
expiration of the term or due to any other cause, Council shall appoint a
successor or successors, or if there should be no members left on the Board,
Council shall appoint successors, and in either event, the appointments shall
be for the unexpired term or terms.
(Passed 10-4-84.)
139.04 OATH; PRESIDENT; SECRETARY.
   (a)   After appointment, the members of the Board of Park and Recreation
Commissioners shall qualify by taking and filing with the Recorder the oath
prescribed by law for public officials, and they shall not be permitted to
serve upon the Board until they have so qualified. If any member of the Board
shall fail to so qualify on or before the date upon which he should assume the
duties of his office, a vacancy shall exist which shall be filled as provided
in Section 
139.03 .
   (b)   At the first meeting held after the first Board has been appointed, as
hereinbefore provided, and thereafter at the first meeting in July of each
year, the members of the Board shall organize by electing one of their number
president, another secretary. The secretary shall keep an accurate record of
all the fiscal affairs of the Board, and shall keep a minute book in which he
shall record the proceedings and transactions of each meeting of the Board.
(Passed 10-4-84.)
139.05 COMPENSATION.
   The members of the Board of Park and Recreation Commissioners shall receive
no compensation for their services but they shall be entitled to reimbursement
for all reasonable and necessary expenses actually incurred in the performance
of their duties as members of the Board. They shall not be personally
interested, directly or indirectly, in any contract entered into by the Board,
or hold any remunerative position in connection with the establishment,
construction, improvement, extension, development, maintenance or operation of
any of the property under their control as members of the Board.
(Passed 10-4-84.)
139.06 OFFICE; EMPLOYEES.
   Council shall furnish the Board of Park and Recreation Commissioners a place
in the Municipal building where it may hold its meetings and keep its records.
The Board sitting as a body shall have complete and exclusive control and
management of all of the properties which shall be operated in connection with
the public park and recreation system for the Municipality, and shall have
power to employ such persons as, in its opinion, may be necessary for the
establishment, construction, improvement, extension, development, maintenance
or operation of the property under its control, at such wages or salaries as it
shall deem proper, and shall have full control of all employees.
(Passed 10-4-84.)
139.07 POWERS.
   The Board of Park and Recreation Commissioners is hereby granted the power
and authority to acquire in the name of the Municipality by purchase, lease or
by exercise of the power of eminent domain, or otherwise, such land or lands as
it determines to be necessary, appropriate, convenient or incidental to the
establishment, construction, improvement, extension, development, maintenance
or operation of a system of public parks, parkways, playgrounds, athletic
fields, stadiums, swimming pools, skating rinks or arenas and other public park
and recreation facilities for the Municipality whether of a like or different
nature.
(Passed 10-4-84.)
139.08 USE OF PROPERTIES.
   The Board of Park and Recreation Commissioners is hereby empowered and
authorized to take title in the name of the Municipality to all real and
personal property acquired by it for the use of the public or useful to the
public in the establishment, construction, improvement, extension, development,
maintenance or operation of all public parks, parkways, playgrounds, athletic
fields, stadiums, swimming pools, skating rinks, or arenas and all other park
and recreational facilities for the Municipality, whether of a like or
different nature, and shall manage and dispose of the same as, in its opinion,
will best serve the interests of the public in carrying out the purposes of
this article. The Municipality and all other public bodies owning real property
intended to be used for public parks and recreation are hereby authorized to
let same for use of the Board, upon approval by Council, to be held by it for
such purposes, and the Board is hereby authorized to receive the same. Nothing
contained in this article shall be construed as limiting the Board from going
beyond the corporate limits of the Municipality, anywhere within the State, to
lease, purchase or otherwise acquire, in the name of the Municipality, any real
property for the purposes herein set forth. The Board shall have the right to
recommend the sale, upon approval by Council, of such part of the real property
that it may acquire by gift, devise, purchase, or otherwise in the name of the
Municipality, as it may determine to be of no advantage in the establishment,
construction, improvement, extension, development, maintenance or operation of
the public parks, parkways, playgrounds, athletic fields, stadiums, swimming
pools, skating rinks or arenas and other public park and recreational
facilities, whether of a like or different nature; except that the Board shall
have power and authority to recommend such sales and conveyance of real
property with approval of Council, as may be necessary, appropriate or
convenient to enable the City to obtain the benefits of West Virginia Article
8-16 or any other similar act or legislative authorization. Under no
circumstances shall any of such real property be sold or conveyed except by
unanimous vote of all of the members of the Board and with approval of Council.
All deeds conveying the real property of the Board shall be executed by the
Municipality acting by and through the Mayor.
(Passed 10-4-84.)
139.09 MAINTENANCE OF FACILITIES.
   The Board of Park and Recreation Commissioners shall have the necessary,
appropriate, convenient and incidental powers and authority to manage and
control all public parks, parkways, playgrounds, athletic fields, stadiums,
swimming pools, skating rinks, or arenas and other public park and recreational
facilities of all kinds used as a part of the public park and recreation system
or as a means of maintaining places of beauty, education and promoting the
health, property, lives, decency, morality and good order of the general
public, and particularly of the inhabitants of the Municipality and vicinity;
to abate or cause to be abated all nuisances affecting same; to regulate or
prohibit the selling of any article, goods, wares or merchandise within the
park and recreation system so designated; to regulate or prohibit the placing
of signs, billboards, posters and advertisements within the park and recreation
system as so designated, or the grounds immediately adjacent thereto; to have
the same kept in good order and free from obstruction for the use and benefit
of the public; to restrict and prohibit vagrants, mendicants, beggars, tramps,
prostitutes or disorderly individuals therefrom; to establish, construct,
improve, extend, develop, maintain and operate such parks, parkways,
playgrounds, athletic fields, stadiums, swimming pools, skating rinks or arenas
and other public park and recreational facilities, whether of a like or
different nature, on any grounds controlled by the Board; to acquire for public
use by lease or otherwise lands either within or without the corporate limits
of the Municipality; to cause any public street, avenue, road, alley, way,
bridle path or walkway, which is a part of the public park and recreation
system, to be graded, drained and surfaced; to construct, maintain and operate
all necessary sewers and water lines in connection with the public park and
recreation system; to do any and all things or acts which may in any way be
necessary, appropriate, convenient or incidental to the use and enjoyment of
the public park and recreational system by the general public as a place or
places of beauty, education, entertainment and recreation.
(Passed 10-4-84.)
139.10 RULES AND REGULATIONS; LEGAL COUNSEL.
   In order to accomplish the foregoing purposes, the Board of Park and
Recreation Commissioners is hereby empowered and authorized to promulgate, and
amend from time to time, such rules and regulations as may be necessary,
appropriate, convenient or incidental thereto. After codification of such rules
and regulations, or any amendments thereto, by ordinance of Council which may
provide penalties for a violation thereof, which codification is hereby
authorized, the Board shall enforce the same by appropriate proceedings in any
proper tribunal in this State, or any county, district or municipality thereof;
and shall employ such police officers as it shall deem proper and necessary.
The Town Attorney shall be the official counsel for the Board and shall advise
it on all legal matters, but the Board may, in its own discretion, employ other
or additional counsel.
(Passed 10-4-84.)
139.11 FEES.
   The Board of Park and Recreation Commissioners may make reasonable charges
to the public for the privilege of using any of the recreational facilities
provided in the park and recreation system and may use the funds so received
for the purpose of establishing, constructing, improving, extending,
developing, maintaining or operating the park and recreation system.
(Passed 10-4-84.)
139.12 APPROPRIATION OF MONEYS.
   In carrying out the purposes of this article, the Board of Park and
Recreation Commissioners is hereby empowered and authorized to receive and
disburse for such purposes, any money appropriated to it by Council, together
with any other funds which may come into its hands by gift, grant, donation,
bequest, devise or from its own operation or otherwise. However, the Board
shall not obligate or expend an amount greater than the sum of one thousand
dollars ($1,000) without prior approval of Council.
(Passed 10-4-84.)
ARTICLE 140
Old High School Building Board (Repealed)
   EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Article
140 was repealed by an Ordinance passed October 1, 2020.
ARTICLE 141
Huse Memorial Park Commission
141.00   Cemetery ownership.
141.01   Established.
141.02   Composition; qualifications, appointment, term and removal of members;
vacancies.
141.03   Annual organizational meeting; officers; compensation; expenditures.
141.04   Treasurer’s bond.
141.05   Deposit and withdrawal of funds.
141.06   Limitations and requirements on expenditures.
141.07   General powers and duties.
141.08   Perpetual Care Fund.
141.09   Fund trustees.
141.10   Annual distribution of Fund income.
141.11   Records and reports of trustees.
141.12   Prohibited transactions.
141.13   Determination of disputes and questions.
141.14   Additional duties.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Cemetery trustees - see W. Va. Code 35-5-1 et seq.
Huse Memorial Park Cemetery - see S.U. & P. S. Art.
951
 
 
 
141.00 CEMETERY OWNERSHIP
   Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, the ownership of and
the fundamental responsibility for the Huse Memorial Park Cemetery will remain
with the Town of Fayetteville, and this article shall not be construed as
compromising that obligation. (Passed 2-5-09)
141.01 ESTABLISHED.
   In the exercise of the general powers of the Town of Fayetteville, there is
hereby created a Municipal Commission which shall be known as and shall
transact all business under the name of Huse Memorial Park Commission, herein
after referred to as the Commission.
(Passed 2-5-09.)
141.02 COMPOSITION; QUALIFICATIONS, APPOINTMENT, TERM AND REMOVAL OF MEMBERS;
VACANCIES.
    (a)   The Huse Memorial Park Commission shall consist of five (5) members,
without reference to sex, or party politics, who shall be appointed by the
Mayor and conformed by the town council. One (1) of whom shall be a member of
the town council and shall be appointed chairperson of the Commission. The
council members of the Commission shall serve for a term coextensive with their
terms as members of town council; and the other members of the Commission shall
be appointed for a term of the following: One (1) for three (3) years, one (1)
for two (2) years and two (2) for five (5) years. Members serve until their
respective successors are appointed and qualified; all vacancies shall be
filled for the unexpired term by council. Members of the Commission may be
removed by town council for without cause, but shall have an opportunity to be
heard at any regular meeting of town council or any special meeting thereof
called for that purpose. (Passed 2-5-09.)
   (b)   Any member who is a councilperson shall serve during his or her term
of office and no member shall serve more than two consecutive terms.
(Ord. 2017-9. Passed 12-7-17.)
141.03 ANNUAL ORGANIZATIONAL MEETING; OFFICERS; COMPENSATION; EXPENDITURES.
   The Commission shall elect from its membership a secretary other officer as
it determines to be necessary for the performance of its duties. The Commission
may adopt such rules as may be necessary for the transaction of its business,
hold regular meetings, and shall keep a record of its official proceedings, a
copy of which shall be filed in the town Recorders office. The members of the
commission and the officers thereof shall serve without compensation as such.
However, the Commission shall have the authority to employ the Town of
Fayetteville clerical employees assistance and to incur reasonable and
necessary expenses, itemize statements of which shall be submitted to town
council with the recommendation of the commission, and shall be paid, upon
approval, from funds budgeted to the Huse Memorial Park Commission. (Passed 2-
5-09.)
141.04 TREASURER’S BOND.
   In the exercise of the general powers of the Town of Fayetteville, the
Treasurer of the Commission, or the Treasurer of the Town of Fayetteville will
serve as a combined office, shall furnish good and adequate bond conditioned
upon the faithful performance of their duties and the paying over of all money
coming into the hands of the Treasurer as required by the Commission by this
article. Such bond shall be with a recognized surety company and in such amount
as required by the Commission, and the premium on such bond shall be paid by
the Commission from funds in its hands. (Passed 2-5-09.)
141.05 DEPOSIT AND WITHDRAWAL OF FUNDS.
   (a)   All funds and revenues of and from the cemetery shall be deposited in
a separate fund in the name of the Commission in some reputable bank or trust
company that Council shall designate for such purpose, and shall be withdrawn
and expended solely for the purpose of the cemetery. No expenditure shall be
made except upon the written approval of the Commission or Council, either or
both, and then only upon checks drawn by the Treasurer of the Commission.
   (b)   The Town Treasurer shall not be liable or responsible for any of the
funds of the Commission nor for any of the funds coming into the hands of the
trustees for the Huse Memorial Park Perpetual Care fund, the collection,
custody and disbursement of such funds, being, by this article, the
responsibility of the Commission.
(1973 Code §12-7; 2-5-09)
141.06 LIMITATIONS AND REQUIREMENTS ON EXPENDITURES.
   The Commission shall authorize all expenditures except as herein otherwise
provided, and any expenditure or contract involving any expenditure in excess
of the sum of five hundred dollars ($500.00) shall be first reported to and
approved by Council. The Commission shall keep true, complete and accurate
records of all sales and interments and other matters pertaining to their
duties, and of their financial transactions as herein provided for. The
Commission shall conduct all of its business and financial transactions in the
name of the “Huse Memorial Park Commission”, and shall in no event obligate or
attempt to obligate, pledge or attempt to pledge the credit of the Town nor
shall the Town or any of its funds or revenues be liable for any debts,
obligation or liabilities of the Commission of its agents, servants or
employees, or of the trustees as herein provided for. The Commission and each
member thereof is hereby prohibited from incurring any debt or obligation in
excess of current resources or entering into any contract or lease for more
than one year without the prior approval of Council.
(1973 Code §12-8; 2-5-09)
141.07 GENERAL POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Commission shall, among other things pertinent to the purposes for which
it is established, lay out, survey, and fix the prices upon all cemetery lots,
and shall cause the lots to be mapped or platted, and a copy thereof, showing
the proposed prices, shall be filed with and shall be subject to the approval
or change of Council; and the Commission shall lay out all roads, entrance-ways
and other necessary improvements, and shall cause them to be constructed and
maintained; it shall likewise provide for the perpetual care, maintenance and
beautification of the cemetery property and shall supervise and direct all work
done or to be done in connection therewith; it shall employ, discharge and fix
the compensation of all employees and, where not otherwise herein provided,
shall have general supervision, management and control of the cemetery property
and its business. All deeds to purchaser shall be executed by the Mayor in the
name and under the seal of the Town. No real estate shall be sold except in the
usual course of the conduct of the cemetery and upon a form or upon forms of
deeds to be approved by Council. The Commission shall have the power and
authority to and shall adopt and promulgate from time to time reasonable rules
and regulations for the restriction, use and operation of the cemetery property
and individual burial lots therein.
(1973 Code §12-9; 2-5-09)
141.08 PERPETUAL CARE FUND.
   (a)   There is hereby created a permanent endowment fund for the perpetual
care, beautification and maintenance of the cemetery which shall be known as
the “Huse Memorial Park Perpetual Care Fund”.
   (b)   Town Council in consultation with the Commission may require
additional funds to be added to the existing Huse Memorial Park Perpetual Care
Fund by requiring a percentage of the gross sales of lots, niches, or crypts to
be paid into said fund.
(Passed 1-5-23.)
141.09 FUND TRUSTEES.
   (a)   The Perpetual Care Fund shall be administered by three trustees, one
of whom shall be appointed by Council from its own membership, one by the
Commission from its own membership, and the third shall be appointed by Council
upon the recommendation of the Commission, and shall be a cemetery-lot owner
who is neither a member of the Commission nor a member of Council. Vacancies
shall be filled in like manner. Each trustee shall be appointed for a period of
two years or until his successor is appointed. No person shall be eligible for
appointment as such trustee except a resident of Fayette County, West Virginia.
Such trustees shall be persons of sound business judgment and discretion with
experience in financial and investment matters. They shall accept the trust in
writing and, upon acceptance, they shall be bound by all of the terms and
provisions of West Virginia Code Article 35-5 and subject to all the duties and
requirements thereof. Such trustees shall draw no compensation except as
authorized by Council.
   (b)   They shall invest the Perpetual Care Funds in conservative, solvent
investments, but no investment shall be made until it shall have been approved
by the Commission, at least three members of the Commission voting in favor
thereof at a meeting regularly called and held, and such approval shall be made
a matter of record by the Commission. The trustees with like approval shall
have the power to sell, exchange, liquidate and reinvest the assets under their
control. The trustees shall be required, before they receive any part of the
fund, to give bond with approved security before Council, each in an amount to
be fixed by the Commission, conditioned upon the faithful discharge of their
duties and to account for and pay over in the manner provided by law all money
coming into their hands as such trustees, and if any expense is incurred in the
giving of a surety bond the same shall be approved and paid by the Commission
out of its general funds. Such bond may be increased or diminished from time to
time, but shall be at least equal to the amount of the fund at any time in the
hands of such trustees. The trustees shall keep all the fund and the income and
profits therefrom in a separate account or accounts in some reputable bank or
trust company designated by Council for such purpose.
(1973 Code §12-11; 2-5-09)
141.10 ANNUAL DISTRIBUTION OF FUND INCOME.
   All income from the Perpetual Care Fund, but in no event any part of the
principal of such Fund, shall at least once each year at the end thereof, and
more often if the Commission shall require, be turned over to the Commission
and shall be used exclusively for the care, maintenance and beautification of
the cemetery and the burial and other lots therein. The Commission shall have
the right to receive charitable bequests, individual donations and other gifts
and contributions to implement such fund, for either special or general
purpose.
(1973 code §12-12; 2-5-09)
141.11 RECORDS AND REPORTS OF TRUSTEES.
   The trustees of the Perpetual Care Fund shall keep true and complete records
of all their financial transactions under this article, and shall make their
reports as required by the laws of West Virginia.
(1973 Code §12-13; 2-5-09)
141.12 PROHIBITED TRANSACTIONS.
   No gain or profit shall be derived by Officials or employees of the Town of
Fayetteville, members or employees of the Huse Memorial Park Commission, Huse
Memorial Park Perpetual Care Trustees, or any individual or corporation charged
with any of the duties or responsibilities hereunder, and any person or
corporation who shall directly or indirectly receive any such gain or profit
from any transaction or activity hereunder shall refund the same upon demand of
Council, and shall be guilt of a violations of this article. Any misfeasance or
malfeasance in office shall likewise be a violation of this article. Nothing in
this article shall prohibit Huse Memorial Park and/or the Town of Fayetteville
from profiting from the sale of merchandise relating to the cemetery, including
but not limited to markers, vases, containers for cremains, etc.
(Passed 10-3-24.)
141.13 DETERMINATION OF DISPUTES AND QUESTIONS.
   Should any questions or dispute arise as between the members of the
Commission or as between the Commission and the trustees as to any matter
involved herein, the same shall be referred to and settled by Council, after
full hearing at a meeting of such Council, and the decision of Council shall be
final and binding and shall be made a part of a minutes of such Council
meeting.
(1973 Code §12-15; 2-5-09)
141.14 ADDITIONAL DUTIES.
   Council may, from time to time, provide such other duties and requirements
for the Commission and the trustees of the Perpetual Care Fund as are not
inconsistent with State law, the Codified Ordinances or other ordinance of
Council.
(1973 Code §12-16; 2-5-09)
ARTICLE 143
Water and Sewer Sanitary Board (Repealed)
   EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Article
143 was repealed by Ordinance passed October 1, 2020.
ARTICLE 145
Employees and Officers Generally
145.01   Liability of Town officers; employees.
145.02   Official bonds.
145.03   Compensation generally; disposition of fees.
145.04   Right of entry for inspection purposes.
145.05   State Employees Retirement System.
145.06   Social security.
145.07   Personnel regulations.
145.08   Officers generally.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Compensation of officers and employees - see W. Va. Code 8-5-12
Conflict of interest - see W. Va. Code 8-5-19
Bonds - see W. Va. Code 8-12-5(46), (47); 6-2-11
Reimbursement of employment applicant - see W. Va. Code 8-12-5(54)
Employee benefit fund - see W. Va. Code 8-12-5(56)
Insurance and indemnification - see W. Va. Code 8-12-7 et seq.
Retirement benefits - see W. Va. Code Art. 8-22
 
 
 
145.01 LIABILITY OF TOWN OFFICERS; EMPLOYEES.
   Nothing in the Codified Ordinances or any other ordinance or resolution of
Council shall be construed to impose any liability upon the Town or upon any
person for any act or omission required or permitted thereby when such act or
omission is otherwise lawful, in good faith, and without malice or mischievous
intent and, when any Town officer or employee is in line of duty and within the
scope of his authority.
(1973 Code §1-8(a))
145.02 OFFICIAL BONDS.
   (a)   Council may adopt a system of blanket faithful performance and honesty
bonding as it deems appropriate.
   (b)   All officers, employees and agents of the Town who, in line of duty,
are required or authorized to carry firearms, shall give bond, payable to the
Town, with corporate surety in such amount not less than ten thousand dollars
($10,000) as may be specified by Council, and conditional upon the faithful
performance of their respective duties and the payment of any judgment or
decree which may be rendered against them for the negligent or unlawful use or
handling of such firearm and to save the Town harmless from all claims and
demands whatsoever for the negligent or unlawful use or handling of such
firearm.
   (c)   The Town Attorney shall approve all bonds required by this section
with respect to their form and legality; and the premiums thereon shall be paid
by the Town. Council shall approve all bonds required by this section with
respect to their sufficiency. All bonds required by this section shall be in
the custody of the Recorder.
(1973 Code §2-1)
145.03 COMPENSATION GENERALLY; DISPOSITION OF FEES.
   (a)   The salary of the Mayor shall be $2,166.67 a month. The salary of the
Recorder shall be $1083.34 a month. The salary of the members of Council shall
be $433.34 a month. The Mayor, Recorder, Council members shall receive as
compensation for their services as provided in the annual budget or other
ordinance of Council.
(Passed 7-7-07)
   (b)   Except as may be provided otherwise in the Codified Ordinance or other
ordinance, all fees paid to Town officers and employees shall be deemed to be
money belonging to the Town, and shall be paid over to the Treasurer by the
recipients thereof not less frequently than once each week. (1973 Code §2-2)
145.04 RIGHT OF ENTRY FOR INSPECTION PURPOSES.
   Whenever any officer or employee of the Town is required or authorized by
statute, the provisions of the Codified Ordinances or any ordinance or
resolution, or rules and regulations or orders issued thereunder, in order to
carry out his duties, to enter any premises or vehicle for the purpose of
making inspection thereof or of anything therein contained, such officer or
employee shall have the right to enter any such premises or vehicle in
accordance with law at any reasonable time in pursuance of such duties.
(1973 Code §2-10)
145.05 STATE EMPLOYEES RETIREMENT SYSTEM.
   Council, having elected on August 1, 1961, by unanimous vote of its members,
to have the Town become a participating public employer and thereby include its
eligible officers and employees in the membership of the State Employees
Retirement System, hereby declares that the Town shall continue to be a
participating public employer and shall conform to all applicable provisions of
West Virginia Code 5-10-1 to 5-10-55.
(1973 Code §2-11)
145.06 SOCIAL SECURITY.
   Council, having heretofore elected to extend the benefits of Title II of the
Federal Social Security Act to all eligible Town officers and employees, as
provided in West Virginia Code 5-7- 5, hereby declares that the plan for
extending those benefits as heretofore submitted to and approved by the State
Auditor in his capacity as the “state agency” shall continue in full force and
effect and that the Town shall conform to all applicable provisions of West
Virginia Code 5-7-1 to 5-7-10. (1973 Code §2-12)
145.07 PERSONNEL REGULATIONS.
   (a)   The Mayor or Council may request that the Town of Fayetteville
Personnel Manual be updated and amended from time to time, not inconsistent
with State and Federal law, prescribing conditions of service or employment and
the official conduct of all Town officers and employees other than elected
officials. The Mayor with the consent of Council may appoint a Committee to
review and suggest amendments to the said Personnel Manual.
(Passed 10-17-24.)
   (b)   Council shall take such action as it may consider appropriate in the
best interests of the Town and the personnel regulated by any such regulation
or amendments so presented to Council; but no such regulations or amendments
shall take effect until approved by resolution of Council or by order of
Council duly entered in its journal, nor until a true copy of such regulations
or amendments thereof has been placed on file in the office of the Recorder.
   (c)   The regulations contemplated by this section may include, but shall
not be limited to, subjects such as:
      (1)   Vacation leave, sick leave and military service leave;
      (2)   Working hours and overtime pay;
      (3)   Disciplinary procedures;
      (4)   Acceptance of gifts or favors for official duty performed or
service rendered in line of duty;
      (5)   Political activities inconsistent with the Town office or position
held; and
      (6)   So called “fringe benefits” such as, for example, group health,
hospital or medical insurance which may at any time be provided by action of
Council.
         (1973 Code §2-13; Passed 5-4-23.)
      (7)   Job descriptions. (Passed 10-17-24.)
   (d)   Council has adopted the Safety Policy Accident Prevention Manual,
attached to an ordinance passed May 4, 2006, which shall provide for the
personal safety of all employees in the Town of Fayetteville, West Virginia. A
copy is on file in the Town offices.
(Passed 5-4-06.)
   (e)   Council has adopted an Employee Personnel Manual which shall be
provided to all employees, and copies of all amendments thereto shall be
provided to all employees within five (5) days of adoption. A copy of the
Employee Personnel Manual and all amendments thereto shall be maintained at
Town Hall. (Passed 10-17-24.)
145.08 OFFICERS GENERALLY.
   (a)   Election: Term. The Mayor, councilpersons, and the Recorder shall be
elected in accordance with Article 10.01. They shall take office on July 1 next
following their election and shall serve a four (4) year term, which shall
expire on the last day of June of the fourth year following their election, or
until their respective successors have been duly elected and have qualified,
unless soon removed from office according to law.
(Passed 10-17-24.)
   (b)   Qualifications. The Mayor, Recorder and councilmen shall be residents
of the Town and legal voters therein.
   (c)   Appointive Town Officer Holding Two Offices. Except as may be provided
otherwise in any case by State law, the Codified Ordinance or other ordinance,
the Town Manager may designate any appointive Town office to hold one or more
other Town appointive offices concurrently, subject to the right of Council to
designate any Town elective officer to hold one or more appointive Town offices
concurrently.
   (d)   Town Elective Officers Not to Hold Other Elective Offices. No Town
elective officer shall hold any elective office of the Federal or State
government or any elective office of the County or any office which is filled
by the electors of a magisterial district or school district.
   (e)   Oath of Office. All Town officers shall take the following oath,
before entering upon their duties, which shall be filed with the Recorder and a
certified copy thereof shall be filed in the office of the County Clerk:
   “I,  name of affiant  , do solemnly swear that I will support the
Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the State of West
Virginia, and that I will freely, faithfully and impartially discharge the
duties of the office upon which I am about to enter to the best of my skill and
judgment.”
   (f)   Conflicts of Interest. No Town officer shall be interested personally,
either directly or indirectly, or as a member, manager, officer or stockholder
of any partnership, business, firm or corporation, in any contract furnishing
material, services or supplies to the Town, or any contractor, or workmen for
the Town, or in any manner whatsoever, whereby the taxpayers of the Town shall
become paymaster, either directly or indirectly; provided, that this section
shall not apply to any such officer who is merely a stockholder of less than
five percent (5%) of the stock of any such corporation and is not an officer or
director of such corporation. Any violation of this section by any member of
Council or by any other Town officer shall be a misdemeanor and, upon
conviction thereof, such member or officer shall be fined not more than five
hundred dollars ($500.00) and shall automatically be removed from office.
   (g)   Administration of Oaths. The Mayor, the presiding officer of Council,
the presiding officer of any Council committee or of any board, commission or
other body of the Town government, and each Town officer, his deputies and
assistants, to whom any sworn report, return, certificate or statement, whether
oral or in writing, is required to be made or submitted by any person pursuant
to any provision of the Codified Ordinances or other ordinance or resolution of
Council shall have authority to administer the oath so required, provided, that
nothing in this section shall be construed as purporting to authorize the
administration of any oath which, by law, is required to be administered by a
judicial officer, notary public or other officer authorized by statute to
administer oaths, nor shall this section be construed as purporting to
authorize the taking of any acknowledgment of any signature or seal for the
purpose of recording in the office of the Clerk of the County Court or
elsewhere other than in the office of the Recorder or some other officer of
this Town.
   (h)   Authority of Deputies, Assistants and Acting Town Officers.
      (1)   Authority vested in and duties imposed upon Town officers, by State
law, the Codified Ordinances or other ordinances and resolutions of Council
may, when they so authorize, be exercised or performed by their deputies,
assistants and other subordinates, to the extent not prohibited by State law,
the Codified Ordinances or other ordinance or resolution of Council.
      (2)   When any Town officer or employee is absent or disabled, or when
any office or position in the Town government is vacant, the person designated
by competent authority to act in the place of such absent or disabled officer
or employee or to temporarily hold the vacant office or position shall have the
powers and perform the duties of such absent or disabled officer or employee or
appertaining to such vacant office or position.
   (i)   Undue Influence Over Town Employees Prohibited.
      (1)   The Mayor and Council and its committees, in exercising lawful
supervision over those departments, office and agencies of the Town government
which are under the supervision and control of the Town Manager, shall deal
therewith only through the Town Manager; provided, that in exceptional cases,
Council may, by resolution which sets out the reason for such exception,
authorize noncompliance with all but the proviso of this subsection.
      (2)   Neither the Mayor nor any councilman shall attempt to influence any
decision or action which by law, the Codified Ordinances or other ordinance, is
authorized to be made or taken by the Town Manager or by any officer, employee
or agent of the Town whose position and duties are subject to supervision and
control by the Town Manager.
      (3)   Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit direct
communication between the Mayor or Council and its committees with any officer,
employee or agent of the Town with respect to any matter for which such person
is whether by law, the Codified Ordinances or other ordinance, responsible
directly to the Mayor or to Council.
         (1973 Code §2-26 to 2-34; Passed 5-4-23.)
ARTICLE 147
Municipal Building Commission
147.01   Commission established.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Municipal building commissions - see W. Va. Code Art. 8-33
 
 
 
147.01 COMMISSION ESTABLISHED.
   (a)   There is hereby formed, created and established a municipal building
commission to be known as the Fayetteville Building Commission (the
Commission). In accordance with West Virginia Code Article 8-33 the Commission
shall be a public corporation and have perpetual existence.
   (b)   The Commission shall have all powers granted by West Virginia Code
Article 8-33 and any other powers granted to it by applicable law.
   (c)   The Board of the Commission shall consist of 3 members.
   (d)   At the conclusion of the term of the appointment of each member of the
Commission, the Town Council of the Town of Fayetteville shall appoint a
successor for a term of 5 years. Not more than 2 of the 3 members of the Board
named above are from the same political party, and no member named above holds
any office (other than the office notary public) or employment under the United
States of America, the State of West Virginia, any county or political
subdivision thereof, or any political party. All members named above are
residents of the Town of Fayetteville.
   (e)   The Commission shall not incur any indebtedness or acquire any
property, real or personal, without the prior written consent of the Town
Council of the Town of Fayetteville.
   (f)   No indebtedness of any nature of the Commission shall constitute an
indebtedness of the Town of Fayetteville, the County of Fayette, or any agency
thereof, except the Commission. No indebtedness or obligations incurred by the
Commission shall give any right against any member of the Town Council of the
Town of Fayetteville or any member of the Commission.
(Passed 7-7-05.)
   (g)   No member shall serve more than two consecutive terms.
(Note: No member of Council should be on this Commission, since no elected
official can serve).
(Ord. 2017-11. Passed 12-7-17.)
ARTICLE 148
Fayetteville Beautification Commission
148.01   Fayetteville Beautification Commission established.
148.02   Purpose.
148.03   Members.
148.04   Officers.
 
 
 
148.01 FAYETTEVILLE BEAUTIFICATION COMMISSION ESTABLISHED.
   There is hereby created a commission to be known as the Town of Fayetteville
Beautification Commission which shall perform services prescribed in this
article to enhance the aesthetic beauty of the Town of Fayetteville.
(Passed 10-4-06)
148.02 PURPOSE.
   (a)   It shall be the duty of the Fayetteville Beautification Commission to
advise and recommend to the Mayor, Town Manager and Council such programs or
projects as would, in the opinion of the Commission, improve the beauty of the
Town of Fayetteville and promote the general welfare of its citizens.
   (b)   The Mayor and Town Manager shall request the advice or cooperation of
the Commission for any project or program connected with the beautification,
cleanliness, or general welfare of the Town of Fayetteville.
   (c)   The Commission shall submit an annual report on or before the first
meeting in April of the Town Council of the Town of Fayetteville to the Mayor,
Town Manager and Town Council, generally outlining a suggested program and/or
progress during the previous year.
(Passed 10-4-06; Passed 5-4-23.)
148.03 MEMBERS.
   (a)    The Commission shall be composed of five (5) members who shall be
appointed by the Mayor and approved by Town Council
   (b)    Members shall be appointed for terms as follows: One (1) Member for a
term of one (1) year, two members for a term of two (2) years and two (2)
members for a term of three (3) years. No member shall serve more than two (2)
consecutive full terms. Thereafter, all appointments shall be for a term of
three (3) years. Members so appointed shall have their respective term start on
the fifteenth (15th) day of September next succeeding their appointment.
Provided, however, that the term for any member of Town Council appointed to
the Commission shall continue during his or her term and until his or her
successors have been duly appointed and qualified. Likewise, the term of any
other appointed members of the Commission shall serve until his or her
successor has been duly appointed and qualified.
   
   (c)    Vacancies shall be filled by appointment for the unexpired term.
   (d)    Members of the Commission shall be reimbursed by the Town of
Fayetteville for their expenses incurred in connection with the performance of
their duties.
   (e)    Any member who fails to attend more than two (2) regularly scheduled
meetings of the Commission may be removed by the Mayor and a new member
appointed for the unexpired term of the member who was removed.
   (f)    The Council may appropriate such funds as it deems appropriate to
finance activities of the Commission.
(Ord. 2017-5. Passed 12-7-17.)
148.04 OFFICERS.
   (a)   The Commission shall elect from its membership a vice-chairman,
secretary, and treasurer and such other officers as it determines to be
necessary for the performance of its duties.
   (b)   The Commission shall hold such meetings and adopt such rules as shall
be necessary for the transaction of its business.
   (c)   All officers named above are residents of the Town of Fayetteville.
   (d)   The Commission shall not incur any indebtedness or acquire any
property, real or personal, without the prior written consent of Council.
   (e)   No indebtedness of any nature of the Commission shall constitute an
indebtedness of the Town, the County, or any agency thereof, except the
Commission. No indebtedness or obligations incurred by the Commission shall
have any right against any member of Council or any member of the Commission.
(Passed 9-6-07)
ARTICLE 149
Addressing and Mapping System
149.01   Applicability.
149.02   Coordination with County addressing program; adoption and addressing
program; penalties for noncompliance.
149.03   Appointment and duties of addressing and mapping coordinators.
149.04   Interpretation and application.
 
 
 
149.01 APPLICABILITY.
   (a)   The provisions of this article apply to all areas of the Town of
Fayetteville, except as may be expressly set forth below.
   (b)   Pursuant to the Emergency Rules of the West Virginia Statewide
Addressing and Mapping Board on file with the office of the Secretary of State,
Title 169, Series 2 of the Code of State Rules, the Town of Fayetteville hereby
elects to participate in the West Virginia Statewide Addressing and Mapping
Project.
(Passed 6-2-05.)
149.02 COORDINATION WITH COUNTY ADDRESSING PROGRAM; ADOPTION AND ADDRESSING
PROGRAM; PENALTIES FOR NONCOMPLIANCE.
   (a)   All provisions of the 9-1-1 Addressing and Mapping Ordinance of the
Fayette County Commission, dated March 2, 2004, including the penalties for
noncompliance, hereby apply within the Town of Fayetteville, Fayette County, as
if fully set forth herein, except as set forth in subsection (b) below.
   (b)   Nothing in this article affects existing City-type addresses, which
are satisfactory for 9-1-1 and emergency services purposes, provided that those
addresses are consistent with the Statewide Addressing and Mapping Project and
otherwise comply with the Rules and Regulations of the West Virginia Statewide
Addressing and Mapping Board.
(Passed 6-2-05.)
149.03 APPOINTMENT AND DUTIES OF ADDRESSING AND MAPPING COORDINATORS.
   (a)   The Fayette County Addressing Coordinator shall act as the Addressing
Coordinator for the Town of Fayetteville. The Addressing Coordinator may not,
however, take any official action not expressly authorized in this article or
in the 9-1-1 Addressing and Mapping Ordinance of Fayette County, dated March 2,
2004, without the approval of the Council of the Town of Fayetteville.
   (b)   The Fayette County Mapping Coordinator shall act as the Mapping
Coordinator for the Town of Fayetteville. The Mapping Coordinator may not,
however, take any official action not expressly authorized in this article or
in the 9-1-1 Addressing and Mapping Ordinance of Fayette County, dated March 2,
2004, without the approval of the Council of the Town of Fayetteville. (Passed
6-2-05.)
149.04 INTERPRETATION AND APPLICATION.
   This article is to be interpreted and applied consistent with the West
Virginia Statewide Addressing and Mapping System. The Addressing Coordinator
and the Mapping Coordinator of the Town of Fayetteville shall make any
necessary application to the Statewide Addressing and Mapping Board for a
waiver, or for local modifications of the Statewide Addressing and Mapping
System in order to tailor it to this article.
(Passed 6-2-05.)
ARTICLE 150
Outstanding Debts or Financial Obligations
150.01   Definitions.
150.02   Outstanding debts or financial obligations.
150.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this article, unless otherwise expressly provided or the context
otherwise requires:
   (a)   Outstanding Debt means the unpaid portion of a debt that may include
interest accrued on the balance.
   (b)   Financial Obligation means an obligation to pay money to the Town of
Fayetteville, West Virginia.
   (c)   Past Due means any outstanding debt or financial obligation that has
not been within thirty (30) days of the due date on the aforesaid debt.
      (Ord. 2012-1. Passed 3-1-12.)
150.02 OUTSTANDING DEBTS OR FINANCIAL OBLIGATIONS.
   Any individual who has any past due outstanding debt or financial obligation
owed to the Town of Fayetteville shall hereby be disqualified from serving on
any board, or commission of the Town of Fayetteville. Provided, if the
individual brings the past due balance of the outstanding debt or financial
obligation current by paying the past due balance, they then shall be permitted
to serve on the respective board or commission upon proper approval of the Town
Council.
(Ord. 2012-1. Passed 3-1-12.)
ARTICLE 151
New River Transit Authority
151.01   Established; members; voting.
151.01 ESTABLISHED; MEMBERS; VOTING.
   (a)   The New River Transit Authority, an Urban Mass Transportation
Authority, is hereby created.
   (b)   Other local governments are likewise participating in the creation of
the New River Transit Authority by adoption of Ordinances, Orders, or
Resolutions.
   (c)   Members of the Authority’s board representing the Town of Fayetteville
shall be appointed in accordance with the provisions of Section 8-27-5 of the
West Virginia Code.
   (d)   The initial member of the Authority’s Board representing the Town of
Fayetteville shall be Mayor/Town Manager, appointed to serve a term of one (1)
year.
   (e)   All subsequent appointments shall be established by Ordinance and
shall be for a term of three years.
   (f)   For the initial fiscal year, each participating government shall
contribute $500.00 to the New River Transit Authority, thereafter, the
contribution shall be determined at the end of each fiscal year by the
Authority in accordance to Section 8-27-5 of West Virginia Code.
   (g)   For the initial fiscal year, each participating government shall be
entitled to one vote, thereafter, the number of votes shall be determined at
the end of each fiscal year by the Authority and such determination shall
govern the ensuing fiscal year, even though additional moneys or property are
contributed during that fiscal year in accordance to Section 8-27-5.
   (h)   All other provisions of Section 8-27-1 et seq. of the West Virginia
Code shall apply to the creation of, participation in, or management of said
Authority.
(Passed 5-1-14; 5-4-23.)
ARTICLE 153
Parking Authority Board
153.01   Purpose.
153.02   Members and terms of office.
153.03   Authority of Board.
CROSS REFERENCES
Parking generally - see TRAF. Art.
307
153.01 PURPOSE.
   It is the intent of the Town Council to facilitate a more efficient method
of modifying existing parking regulations than requiring action of Town Council
to pass an ordinance for every change in parking restrictions, limitations and
locations. The Parking Authority Board is hereby formed for that purpose. (Ord.
2017-6. Passed 12-7-17.)
153.02 MEMBERS AND TERMS OF OFFICE.
   (a)   The Parking Authority Board shall consist of five (5) members: The
Town Manager, the Chief of Police, a member of Town Council, appointed by the
Mayor and approved by Council, a resident of the Town of Fayetteville, who
shall be appointed for a term of four (4) years, and a member of the business
community who is a resident of the Town of Fayetteville and who is an owner of
a business located within the Town of Fayetteville, or who is in a management
position of a business located within the Town of Fayetteville, who shall serve
a term of four (4) years.
   (b)   The member of Council may not serve more than his or her term of
office and the resident and business person may not serve for more than two
consecutive terms.
   (c)   The Board shall meet annually on a date to be selected by them to
review the existing parking restrictions and prohibited parking areas and on
any other occasion as is necessary to form the function for which it has been
created.
(Ord. 2017-6; Passed 12-7-17; Passed 5-4-23.)
153.03 AUTHORITY OF BOARD.
   (a)   The Board shall designate streets and public places, or portions
thereof, within the Town upon which or at which parking shall be prohibited,
restricted or limited in such manner and to such extent as may be considered
necessary by them for the regulation of the use of such
streets and public places in the best interests of the public, and may direct
the Street Commission to place or cause to be placed traffic-control signs at
such places to give notice of the prohibitions, restrictions or limitations
imposed.
   (b)   Included within the meaning of this section are traffic-control signs
and markings, among others not specified herein, as follows:
      (1)   No parking at any time;
      (2)   No parking between certain hours;
      (3)   Two hour parking or other time limits;
      (4)   Parking prohibited except at certain days and/or times;
      (5)   No parking this side of street;
      (6)   No parking from here to corner;
      (7)   Bus stop;
      (8)   Safety zone;
      (9)   Physician parking only;
      (10)   Official cars only;
      (11)   Loading zone;
      (12)   Other prohibitions, restrictions and limitations on parking, as
may be deemed necessary by them.
   (c)   Any changes made by the Board shall be reduced to writing and filed
with and retained in the Office of the Fayetteville Police Department and with
the Town Recorder to be filed in the Traffic Code Section of the Ordinances of
the Town.
   (d)   The provisions of Section
307.18 regarding parking shall remain in full force and effect subject to
changes being made hereafter by action taken pursuant to the authority of the
Parking Authority Board.
(Ord. 2017-6. Passed 12-7-17.)
ARTICLE 154
Commission, Committee or Board Member Emeritus
154.01   Membership.
154.02   Term of appointment.
154.03   Rights, duties and responsibilities.
154.01 MEMBERSHIP.
   The Town Council may appoint at the recommendation of the Mayor or any
member of Council, an individual who has served on a Commission, Committee or
Board of the Town with distinction and dedication and has had to be replaced on
that Commission, Committee or Board as a result of the term limit on that
position. In making such appointment the Council shall consider the number of
years of service to the Town on the Commission, Committee or Board, the
person’s experience and knowledge of the matters handled by the Commission,
Committee or Board and the importance of that experience and knowledge to the
Commission, Committee or Board. (Passed 7-2020.)
154.02 TERM OF APPOINTMENT.
   The Emeritus position hereby established shall be a permanent position once
appointed. The Emeritus position can not be used for the purpose of
establishing a quorum for the Commission, Committee or the Board and will not
have a vote.
(Passed 7-2020.)
154.03 RIGHTS, DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES.
   The Emeritus position shall receive notification of all meetings, all
information provided other members of the Commission, Committee or Board, and
shall be afforded full opportunity to participate in the meetings, including
Executive Session.
(Passed 7-2020.)
CHAPTER SEVEN - Judicial
Art.
171. Municipal Court.
ARTICLE 171
Municipal Court
171.01   Jurisdiction.
171.02   Municipal Judge; qualifications.
171.03   Method of selection; term of office.
171.04   Acting Municipal Judge.
171.05   Municipal Judge; powers and duties.
171.06   Municipal Court; process.
171.07   Fines and fees.
171.08   Municipal Court costs.
171.09   Police Equipment Fund and Police Contingency Fund.
 
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Municipal Court for municipalities - see W. Va. Code 8-10-2
Suspension of license - see W. Va. Code 8-10-2(a), (b)
Recorder to perform Mayor’s duties when Mayor unavailable - see W. Va. Code 8-
10-3
 
 
 
171.01 JURISDICTION.
   There shall be a Municipal Court which shall have criminal jurisdiction over
violations of Town ordinances, the criminal jurisdiction of a Magistrate of the
State of West Virginia, and such other jurisdiction authorized by law.
(Passed 8-20-03.)
171.02 MUNICIPAL JUDGE; QUALIFICATIONS.
   The Judge of the Municipal Court shall be an attorney licensed to practice
law in the State of West Virginia and shall have been admitted to practice
before the Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia and before the United
States District Court for the Southern District of West Virginia. He or she
shall have practiced law in this State for at least five years and shall be a
resident and qualified elector of the State of West Virginia. The Judge of the
Municipal Court shall, immediately upon appointment and, in any event, prior to
performing any duties as Judge, be administered the appropriate oath of his or
her office by a sitting Judge of the Circuit Court of Fayette County, West
Virginia, or by a Justice of the Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia.
(Passed 8-20-03.)
171.03 METHOD OF SELECTION; TERM OF OFFICE.
   The Judge of the Municipal Court shall be appointed by resolution of Council
upon recommendation of the Mayor, and shall serve at the will and pleasure of
the Council for a term which shall not extend beyond the term of the Council
appointing him or her. Council shall set compensation for the Judge of the
Municipal Court, which shall be in no way be associated with or dependent upon
fines or fees imposed or collected, and may, from time to time, adjust such
compensation.
(Passed 8-20-03.)
171.04 ACTING MUNICIPAL JUDGE.
   In the event of the temporary absence of the Municipal Judge, the Mayor
shall serve as Acting Municipal Judge or shall appoint a person with the same
qualifications required of the Municipal Judge, to serve as Acting Municipal
Judge during such absence. If the Mayor is unable to serve as Acting Municipal
Judge in the event of the temporary absence of the Municipal Judge or shall not
have so appointed an Acting Municipal Judge, the Recorder shall serve as Acting
Municipal Judge or shall appoint a person with the same qualifications required
of the Municipal Judge, to serve as Acting Municipal Judge, during such
absence.
(Passed 8-20-03.)
171.05 MUNICIPAL JUDGE; POWERS AND DUTIES.
   (a)   The Judge of the Municipal Court shall preside over the Municipal
Court and, with respect to offenses over which the Municipal Court has
jurisdiction, he or she shall have all the powers and duties which a Magistrate
has with regard to violation of the criminal law of the State of West Virginia.
The Municipal Judge shall have power to issue warrants, upon complaint under
oath of any person or officer, for the arrest of anyone charged with any
municipal offense within the jurisdiction of the Court or for search and
seizure in connection with violation of a municipal ordinance.
   (b)   The Municipal Judge shall try and determine all cases over which the
Court has jurisdiction and, within the limits prescribed by ordinance or
general law, shall have power to punish by fine, imprisonment or both. The
Municipal Judge shall have power to summon persons or subpoena witnesses for
the trial of any case before the Court, to compel the attendance of police
officers of the Town or to require the Chief of Police to enforce all judgments
or orders entered by the Court in the exercise of its powers. In Municipal
Court proceedings for the recovery of fines or for the enforcement of penalties
fixed by ordinance or other law, the Court shall, so far as applicable, conform
to the provisions of general law governing civil proceedings before a
Magistrate of the State of West Virginia. The Municipal Judge shall have such
other powers and duties as Council may by ordinance provide pursuant to general
law.
(Passed 8-20-03.)
171.06 MUNICIPAL COURT; PROCESS.
   All warrants and other process and orders of the Municipal Court shall be
signed by the Municipal Judge and may be directed to the Chief of Police, to be
executed by him, her or by one of his or her subordinates at any place within
the police jurisdiction of the Town. The officer executing any such warrant,
process or order shall have the same liability as a County Sheriff of the State
of West Virginia in the performance of like duties or services.
(Passed 8-20-03.)
171.07 FINES AND FEES.
   All fines and fees received by the Municipal Court shall be paid over to the
Treasurer to be disposed of as prescribed by ordinance or general law.
(Passed 8-20-03.)
171.08 MUNICIPAL COURT COSTS.
   (a)   For any offense which results in a conviction, the costs to be
assessed by the Municipal Court shall be thirty dollars ($30.00), five dollars
($5.00) of which shall be for the purpose of providing support for the
operation of the Fayette County Teen Court Program as authorized by West
Virginia Code §49-5-13d(d).
(Passed 5-5-22.)
   (b)   The costs set forth in subsection (a) above shall be in addition to
any fines, forfeitures or penalties imposed by the Municipal Court Judge and,
further, in addition to any fines, costs, forfeitures or penalties imposed by
State law.
   (c)   Monies received from court costs assessed and monies received from any
fines, forfeitures, or penalties imposed by the Municipal Court Judge shall be
deposited in the General Fund. Therefrom shall be paid to the State of West
Virginia all amounts for fines, costs, forfeitures, or penalties required to be
assessed, collected and paid by State law.
   (d)   Court costs shall be assessed upon conviction and shall not be waived.
Conviction includes being found guilty at trial and pleas of guilty or nolo
contendere. If the case is deferred or continued generally, if the defendant is
placed on probation or if the defendant is permitted to take a defensive
driving safety course, court costs shall nevertheless be assessed by the
Municipal Court.
   (e)   If a defendant demands a jury trial and is subsequently convicted, the
additional costs of the jury trial, if any, shall, in addition to all other
fines, costs, forfeitures or penalties imposed by this article, or other law,
be assessed against the defendant.
   (f)   If a warrant has been issued, an additional $35.00 processing fee
shall be assessed against the defendant upon conviction.
   (g)   If a defendant is permitted time to pay any fines, costs, forfeitures
or penalties, or is given a time payment plan, such defendant shall be assessed
a $25.00 time payment fee.
(Passed 9-6-01.)
   (h)   If a defendant’s privilege to operate a motor vehicle in this State is
suspended or revoked by the Town for failure warranting suspension or
revocation of such privilege, such defendant shall be assessed a $15.00
suspension/revocation fee.
(Passed 5-8-03; 10-1-20.)
171.09 POLICE EQUIPMENT FUND AND POLICE CONTINGENCY FUND.
   (a)   There is hereby created a Police Equipment Fund which shall be funded
by the payment of fifteen dollars ($15.00) from the General Fund into that Fund
for every conviction in the Municipal Court of the Town.
   (b)   There is hereby created a Police Contingency Fund which shall be
funded by the payment of ten dollars ($10.00) from the General Fund into that
Fund for every conviction in the Municipal Court of the Town.
(Passed 10-1-20.)
CODIFIED ORDINANCES OF FAYETTEVILLE
PART TWO - MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS
                                                                                                
         Art.
202. Sale or Lease of Town Property.
CODIFIED ORDINANCES OF FAYETTEVILLE
PART TWO - MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS
ARTICLE 202
Sale or Lease of Town Property
202.01   Sale or lease of Town property for public purpose.
202.02   Sale of Town property at auction.
202.03   Sale of Town property by sealed bids.
202.04   Exemption from public auction for personal property.
202.05   Sale of real estate without auction.
202.06   Approval of sale of Town property.
202.07    Lease of Town property.
202.01 SALE OR LEASE OF TOWN PROPERTY FOR PUBLIC PURPOSE.
   The Town or the Town Building Commission is authorized to sell, lease as
lessor, or dispose of any of its real or personal property or any interest
therein or any part thereof as authorized by West Virginia Code Chapter 1,
Article 5, Section 1, et seq., or to the United States of America or any agency
or instrumentality thereof, for a public purpose for an adequate consideration,
without considering alone the present commercial or market value of such
property.
(Passed 12-2-21.)
202.02 SALE OF TOWN PROPERTY AT AUCTION.
   The Town may sell any of its real or personal property, or any interest
therein or part thereof for a fair and adequate consideration. The property may
be sold at a public auction at a place and time to be designated by the Town
Council, or by using an Internet-based public auction service; but before
making any sale, notice of the time, terms, and place of sale, together with a
brief description of the property to be sold, shall be published as a Class II
legal advertisement in compliance with the provisions of West Virginia Code
Chapter 59, Article 3, Section 1, et seq., and the publication area for the
publication shall be the Town and any other area that Council deems
appropriate. (Passed 12-2-21.)
202.03 SALE OF TOWN PROPERTY BY SEALED BIDS.
   (a)   The Town may sell any of its real or personal property, or any
interest therein or part thereof for a fair and adequate consideration, by
accepting sealed bids for the property, but before making any sale, notice of
the time, terms, and place of sale, together with a brief description of the
property to be sold, shall be published as a Class II legal advertisement in
compliance with the provisions of West Virginia Code Chapter 59, Article 3,
Section 1, et seq., and the publication area for the publication shall be the
Town and any other area that Council deems appropriate.
   (b)   In seeking bids for the sale of real property owned by the Town, the
Town may require submission of plans for the development of the property and
may restrict the use of the property being sold and require specific
development of the property to facilitate economic development projects and/or
to provide a necessary and convenient resource for the benefit of the residents
of the Town.
   (c)   In considering the bids submitted, the Council may consider: the price
to be paid for the property to be sold, the project submitted, the experience,
expertise, and prior success on similar projects exhibited by the bidder.
(Passed 12-2-21.)
202.04 EXEMPTION FROM PUBLIC AUCTION FOR PERSONAL PROPERTY.
   In the event that the property sought to be sold by the Town has a value of
less than fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00), the Town may sell such
property or any interest therein or part thereof for a fair and adequate
consideration and to do so without the use of the public auction procedure;
provided, that:
   (a)   An examination of any personal property to be sold is made by a
qualified, competent person to determine the condition of the property and a
fair value for the same.
   (b)   Every sale of Town property having a market value of less than fifteen
thousand dollars ($15,000.00), shall be authorized by resolution of the Town
Council, which resolution may specify terms and conditions of any such sale;
provided, that before any proposed sale is authorized by resolution of the Town
Council, a public hearing on the proposed sale shall be held by Town Council
after notice of the date, time, place and purpose of the public hearing,
together with a brief description of the property to be sold, has been
published as a Class I legal advertisement in
compliance with the provisions of West Virginia Code Chapter 59, Article 3,
Section 1, et seq., and the publication area shall be the Town.
      (Passed 12-2-21.)
202.05 SALE OF REAL ESTATE WITHOUT AUCTION.
   (a)   Council may sell any real estate owned by the Town, regardless of the
value, without an auction or sealed bids by listing the property itself or by
the use of a realtor and, in either case, by listing the real estate for sale
on a national or statewide listing such as MLS or Zillow, for a minimum of
thirty (30) days.
   (b)   Council may restrict the use of the property being sold and require
specific development of the property to facilitate economic development
projects and/or to provide necessary and convenient resource for the benefit of
the residents of the Town. In doing so, Council may require the prospective
purchaser to submit a plan with an overview of the proposed project, documents
exhibiting the prospective purchaser's experience and expertise in developing
the properties similar to the proposed project, and the purchaser's experience
and expertise in operating similar projects.
(Passed 12-2-21.)
202.06 APPROVAL OF SALE OF TOWN PROPERTY.
   (a)   Before any property, real or personal, of the Town is offered for sale
the Town Council shall make a determination that the property is no longer
needed for Town purposes and/or that the value of the property to the Town is
less than the cost to maintain the property.
   (b)   Before any sale of property is final, Council at a regular or special
meeting must approve the sales price for the property, regardless of the manner
in which it is sold. In the case of sealed bids, Council may make that decision
at the time the bids are opened or at a subsequent regular or special meeting
thereof.
(Passed 12-2-21.)
202.07 LEASE OF TOWN PROPERTY.
   The Town may lease as lessor any of its real or personal property or any
interest therein or any part thereof for a fair and adequate consideration and
for a term not exceeding fifty (50) years. Every lease shall be authorized by
resolution of the Council and Council shall by that resolution specify the
terms and conditions which must be contained in such lease: Provided; that
before any proposed lease is authorized by Council, a public hearing on the
proposed lease shall be held by the Council after a notice of the date, time,
place and purpose of the public hearing has been published as a Class I legal
advertisement as provided in West Virginia Code Chapter 59, Article 3, Section
1, et seq. and the publication area shall be the Town.
(Passed 12-2-21.)
